data.text:
Those of us who remember Joe DiMaggio

as the Yankee Clipper and not Mr. Coffee remember his peerless style and grace,

the 56-game hitting streak, the summer of '41 and Marilyn Monroe.

But the man behind the heroic myth

was quite different. The private DiMaggio was untrusting and distant, greedy

and arrogant, unforgiving and petty, according to an unauthorized biography

published soon after DiMaggio's death in 1999. And though longtime DiMaggio

confidant Morris Engelberg and Associated Press sportswriter Marv Schneider

reportedly aim to set the record straight, as the title suggests, what they

actually do is set that unflattering image in stone.

Author Richard Ben Cramer, in his

2000 biography ''Joe DiMaggio: The Hero's Life,'' publicly laid bare DiMaggio's

faults, which were already well known in some baseball circles. But Cramer also

took some shots at Engelberg, a Hollywood attorney who handled most of DiMaggio's

business and personal affairs for the last 16 years of his life.

Cramer's claims that Engelberg sold

signed memorabilia behind DiMaggio's back are vehemently denied by Engelberg.

As a result, ''Setting the Record Straight'' devotes just 60 pages to the Yankee

Clipper's baseball career and only one chapter to Monroe -- she had a big rear

end and hair on her arms, DiMaggio told Engelberg -- while the tedious details

of memorabilia shows and autograph signings are given far too much space.

But what makes this book special

is the access Engelberg had to DiMaggio's private life, including a diary the

former ballplayer meticulously maintained. And although Engelberg recalls examples

of DiMaggio's charity and how his larger-than-life persona affected others,

he also shows DiMaggio going out of his way to belittle some people and humiliate

others, including two presidents.

DiMaggio refused several entreaties

from Bill Clinton and hated the Kennedys because he was convinced they had a

role in Monroe's death. And though he liked Ronald Reagan, he basically ignored

the former president and his wife, Nancy, when the Reagans called out to him

in a crowded Los Angeles restaurant.

The DiMaggio Engelberg describes

was often mean, and he got away with it because of who he was. In 1998, for

example, the Italian-American Sports Hall of Fame held a black-tie banquet to

celebrate the unveiling of a DiMaggio statue, an event made possible by Hall

leader George Randazzo, who had been the target of DiMaggio slights for two

decades. On the night of the dinner, DiMaggio seemed in a good mood, so Randazzo

asked him to sign the place cards of the celebrities at the head table. When

DiMaggio got to Randazzo's, he looked at the card and said, ''The train stops

here,'' and refused to sign.

Although he was worth tens of millions

of dollars, DiMaggio never picked up a restaurant check and once complained

that Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel never paid him for the use of his name in

their hit song ''Mrs. Robinson.'' He was famous for showing up at celebrity

golf tournaments without his clubs, forcing sponsors to supply him with a new

set. And he rarely left without the TVs or electric razors they gave out as

prizes.

''Setting the Record Straight''

is an unflattering portrait of an American hero and one that leaves you with

admiration and scorn for its author. While Engelberg's devotion to the truth

is commendable, his book also removes the veil from one of the most private

of men, forever altering the way he'll be remembered. Where have you gone, Joe

DiMaggio?
